headline: Earnings 2025: Tariffs spur mass corporate guidance pullback
summary: Tariffs are rattling markets and earnings season, prompting major companies to pull their 2025 guidance altogether. Market Domination host Julie Hyman breaks down how companies, including Kimberly-Clark (KMB), 3M (MMM), and RTX (RTX) are warning of shifting supply chains to absorb the impact of President Trump's tariffs. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Why Kimberly-Clark Stock Was Swooning on Tuesday
summary: An unwelcome change in guidance was the development pushing down Kimberly-Clark's (NYSE: KMB) share price on Tuesday.  In mid-afternoon trading, Kimberly-Clark's stock was down by almost 3% as a result.  Kimberly-Clark's first quarter of 2025 saw the company earn $4.84 billion in net sales, a figure that was down 6% from the same period of 2024.

headline: Kimberly-Clark cuts outlook, PulteGroup earnings, bitcoin rallies
summary: Julie Hyman outlines some of the top stories on Wall Street as part of today's Market Minute. Kimberly-Clark (KMB) cuts its full-year profit outlook, with the Huggies and Kleenex maker citing $300 million in tariff costs. PulteGroup's (PHM) first quarter results beat on the bottom and top lines. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) is trading near $91,000 for the first time since February. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Stocks to Watch Tuesday: First Solar, 3M, Equifax, Tesla
summary: ↗️ 3M (MMM): The materials maker held its 2025 adjusted earnings outlook at $7.60 to $7.90 a share, but said tariffs could knock up to 40 cents off it. The stock jumped 8%. ↗️ Tesla (TSLA): Analysts expect the EV maker to report an on-the-year drop in quarterly profit after markets close.

headline: Kimberly-Clark CEO Warns Tariffs Could Boost Costs. The Stock Is Down.
summary: Kimberly-Clark  stock tumbled Tuesday after the owner of Kleenex and Huggies trimmed its full-year guidance and said tariffs could nudge costs higher.  Kimberly-Clark  posted adjusted earnings of $1.93 a share in the first quarter, slightly beating analysts’ calls for $1.90 a share.  Kimberly-Clark stock was down 3% to $135.92, after falling even lower in premarket trading.

Kimberly-Clark  posted adjusted earnings of $1.93 a share in the first quarter, slightly beating analysts’ calls for $1.90 a share.  Kimberly-Clark stock was down 3% to $135.92, after falling even lower in premarket trading.

headline: Kimberly-Clark Lowers Profit Forecast, Citing ‘Geopolitical Landscape’
summary: Kimberly-Clark lowered its profit forecast for the year, in part due to “changes in the global geopolitical landscape.” The maker of Huggies diapers and Scott paper towels now expects its adjusted operating profit to be flat or slightly positive versus last year, stripping out currency fluctuations.

headline: Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) Reports Sales Below Analyst Estimates In Q1 Earnings
summary: Household products company Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) missed Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q1 CY2025, with sales falling 6% year on year to $4.84 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.93 per share was 2% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

raw.headline: Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) Reports Sales Below Analyst Estimates In Q1 Earnings
raw.summary: Household products company Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) missed Wall Street’s revenue expectations in Q1 CY2025, with sales falling 6% year on year to $4.84 billion. Its non-GAAP profit of $1.93 per share was 2% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Kimberly-Clark cuts 2025 profit forecast as tariffs set to drive up costs
summary: (Reuters) -Kimberly-Clark slashed its annual profit forecast on Tuesday as the Kleenex tissue maker said it would incur about $300 million in costs this year due to U.S. President Donald Trump's broad trade tariffs.  While Trump's efforts to impose import taxes on goods from major U.S. trading partners and many core products are expected to lead to a surge in prices for American consumers, Kimberly-Clark has said it manufactures a vast majority of its products domestically, with imports from Canada, Mexico and China representing less than 10% of the U.S. cost of goods sold.  "The current environment will now mean greater costs across our global supply-chain versus our expectations at the beginning of the year," Kimberly-Clark CEO Mike Hsu said.

raw.headline: Kimberly-Clark cuts 2025 profit forecast as tariffs set to drive up costs
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Kimberly-Clark slashed its annual profit forecast on Tuesday as the Kleenex tissue maker said it would incur about $300 million in costs this year due to U.S. President Donald Trump's broad trade tariffs.  While Trump's efforts to impose import taxes on goods from major U.S. trading partners and many core products are expected to lead to a surge in prices for American consumers, Kimberly-Clark has said it manufactures a vast majority of its products domestically, with imports from Canada, Mexico and China representing less than 10% of the U.S. cost of goods sold.  "The current environment will now mean greater costs across our global supply-chain versus our expectations at the beginning of the year," Kimberly-Clark CEO Mike Hsu said.

headline: Kimberly-Clark cuts annual profit forecast as tariffs set to drive up costs
summary: The company now expects adjusted earnings per share to be flat to positive on a constant-currency basis in 2025, compared to its prior expectations of profit growth in a mid-to-high single-digit percentage range.  "The current environment will now mean greater costs across our global supply-chain versus our expectations at the beginning of the year," Kimberly-Clark CEO Mike Hsu said.

raw.headline: Kimberly-Clark cuts annual profit forecast as tariffs set to drive up costs
raw.summary: The company now expects adjusted earnings per share to be flat to positive on a constant-currency basis in 2025, compared to its prior expectations of profit growth in a mid-to-high single-digit percentage range.  "The current environment will now mean greater costs across our global supply-chain versus our expectations at the beginning of the year," Kimberly-Clark CEO Mike Hsu said.
